metadata_frame: The following passage comes from The Temple of Solomon : a Review of the Various Theories Respecting its Form and Style of Architecture : the Ethics of art : two Lectures, a collection of lectures about art published in 1887 by Edward Cookworthy Robins, a British architect and author.
main_question:
The artists Hiram furnished to Solomon, for the construction and adornment of his Temple and palace, represented the skill of the nation; it comprehended every branch of art, working in gold and silver, in brass and iron,
in purple and blue, in stone and timber, in fine linen and in the engraving of precious stones. Phoenicia had inexhaustible supplies of cedar and fir. [masked sentence describing an inference or effect] All the internal work of 

Solomon's temple, instead of sculpture, was carved work, of olive wood, cedar and gold, with which the walls were lined.

Write a sentence appropriate for this book that could stand in the position marked by [masked sentence describing an inference or effect]:
source_title: The Temple of Solomon : a Review of the Various Theories Respecting its Form and Style of Architecture : the Ethics of art : two Lectures
answer_strings: Hence it was natural that wood should be the prevailing material of Phoenician architecture, while it was almost banished from that of Egypt.
Hence it was unnatural that wood should be the prevailing material of Phoenician architecture, while it was almost embraced in that of Egypt.

Thus the style of art prevailing at the period in the capital of Phoenicia would, doubtless, be stamped on every part, and we are interested to know what may have been the style peculiar to Phoenicia, if indeed it was peculiar to it, seeing that there are no remains of native art existing which can be safely depended upon.
This influx of skilled artists and abundant materials likely resulted in the creation of a masterpiece of architectural beauty and intricate design.
The result was an interior that glowed with the richness of cedar and gold, a testament to the artisans' skill.
passage:
The artists Hiram furnished to Solomon, for the construction and adornment of his Temple and palace, represented the skill of the nation; it comprehended every branch of art, working in gold and silver, in brass and iron,
in purple and blue, in stone and timber, in fine linen and in the engraving of precious stones. Phoenicia had inexhaustible supplies of cedar and fir. Hence it was natural that wood should be the prevailing material of Phoenician architecture, while it was almost banished from that of Egypt. All the internal work of 

Solomon's temple, instead of sculpture, was carved work, of olive wood, cedar and gold, with which the walls were lined.

metadata_frame: The following passage comes from The Temple of Solomon : a Review of the Various Theories Respecting its Form and Style of Architecture : the Ethics of art : two Lectures, a collection of lectures about art published in 1887 by Edward Cookworthy Robins, a British architect and author.
main_question:
The description in Kings, 21st verse, is, "Solomon overlaid the house within with pure gold, and he made a partition by the chains of gold before the oracle,” in which bronze columns may have been introduced to carry the additional height of the end wall of the sanctuary. Canina's arrangement of the chambers round the house I think most correct. Neither their number nor their length is given in Kings or Chronicles, [masked clause acknowledging a countervailing fact]. Ezekiel, in his vision of the restored temple, tells us that "the side chambers were three, one over another, and thirty in order," that is, thirty in all on the sides of the house, besides those at the end of the oracle.

Write a clause appropriate for this book that could stand in the position marked by [masked clause acknowledging a countervailing fact]:
source_title: The Temple of Solomon : a Review of the Various Theories Respecting its Form and Style of Architecture : the Ethics of art : two Lectures
answer_strings: though the former gives their width and height, while the latter does not mention them at all
though neither gives their width nor mentions their height
though they might very reasonably have done so
though Chronicles seems to double that given in Kings; but they are three times mentioned as 18 cubits high, twice in Kings and once in Jeremiah
however, some scholars dispute the accuracy of this interpretation
yet the prophetic vision in Ezekiel supplies a count
passage: The description in Kings, 21st verse, is, "Solomon overlaid the house within with pure gold, and he made a partition by the chains of gold before the oracle,” in which bronze columns may have been introduced to carry the additional height of the end wall of the sanctuary. Canina's arrangement of the chambers round the house I think most correct. Neither their number nor their length is given in Kings or Chronicles, though the former gives their width and height, while the latter does not mention them at all. Ezekiel, in his vision of the restored temple, tells us that "the side chambers were three, one over another, and thirty in order," that is, thirty in all on the sides of the house, besides those at the end of the oracle.

metadata_frame: The following passage comes from The Temple of Solomon : a Review of the Various Theories Respecting its Form and Style of Architecture : the Ethics of art : two Lectures, a collection of lectures about art published in 1887 by Edward Cookworthy Robins, a British architect and author.
main_question:
The "Sister's Kiss," the "Tangled Skein," and the "Music 

Lesson," were marvels of beauty and pure sentiment: "Roses that bathe about the well of life," each an epitome of "sweetness and light," of delicate innocence and loveliness redeeming the voluptuous sensuousness of his dazzling odalisques. [masked sentence describing a tension or contrast] A dream of fair women, or sleeping beauties classically clad, might express its whole meaning.

Write a sentence appropriate for this book that could stand in the position marked by [masked sentence describing a tension or contrast]:
source_title: The Temple of Solomon : a Review of the Various Theories Respecting its Form and Style of Architecture : the Ethics of art : two Lectures
answer_strings: But the picture of the past year, and the last of his greater efforts, seems to me to fail on the ethical side.
But the picture of the past year, and the last of his lesser efforts, seems to me to succeed on the ethical side.
But before all is the feeling it inspires of sweet intelligence and womanly winsomeness.

But the skill of the accomplished artist, whose aims are lofty and true, elevates and glorifies his ideal, and gives to his subject the refinement that comes of sweet unconscious- His nude figures (if they should appear in answer to historical or archæological accuracy, representing national customs or poetic license) will not know that they are so, and will not suggest to the pure anything but the purity that conceives them.
Yet they stood in stark contrast to his darker, more provocative works.
Yet the tender glow of these compositions was counterpointed by a quiet undercurrent of longing, a hint of the raw desire that lay beneath the veneer of innocence.
passage:
The "Sister's Kiss," the "Tangled Skein," and the "Music 

Lesson," were marvels of beauty and pure sentiment: "Roses that bathe about the well of life," each an epitome of "sweetness and light," of delicate innocence and loveliness redeeming the voluptuous sensuousness of his dazzling odalisques. But the picture of the past year, and the last of his greater efforts, seems to me to fail on the ethical side. A dream of fair women, or sleeping beauties classically clad, might express its whole meaning.

main_question:
In fact, it is affirmed that the porch, of which the whole internal depth was 10 cubits, rose to a height exceeding by several feet the ball of fire crowning the monument of London, which be it remembered, was entirely over-laid with pure gold! It is correctly stated, [masked clause describing a tension or contrast]. But "the 

Lord had said that he would dwell in thick darkness."

source_title: The Temple of Solomon : a Review of the Various Theories Respecting its Form and Style of Architecture : the Ethics of art : two Lectures
answer_strings: however, that the Oracle or Holy of Holies of Solomon's Temple, like unto the Tabernacle, had no light, neither windows, nor candlestick, and if it had had the one it would also have had the other
however, that the Oracle or Holy of Holies of Solomon's Temple was brilliantly illuminated with windows and lampstands

but he has increased the length of the sanctuary by the thickness of the wall separating the oracle therefrom; whereas, in every description in the Bible, the whole length of the house is given as threescore cubits, and the separation of 20 cubits for the oracle was afterwards made
but this was too much to give up without taking something in return, so while the Bible says they were made of "olive tree," Josephus declares they were of " solid gold!"
despite its opulent exterior, was starkly bare and humbling within

passage:
In fact, it is affirmed that the porch, of which the whole internal depth was 10 cubits, rose to a height exceeding by several feet the ball of fire crowning the monument of London, which be it remembered, was entirely over-laid with pure gold! It is correctly stated, however, that the Oracle or Holy of Holies of Solomon's Temple, like unto the Tabernacle, had no light, neither windows, nor candlestick, and if it had had the one it would also have had the other. But "the 

Lord had said that he would dwell in thick darkness."

metadata_frame: The following passage comes from The Temple of Solomon : a Review of the Various Theories Respecting its Form and Style of Architecture : the Ethics of art : two Lectures, a collection of lectures about art published in 1887 by Edward Cookworthy Robins, a British architect and author.
main_question:
"And so will I go in unto the King and if I perish I perish." A supreme self sacrifice for a Nation's redemption. There was a law that not even the Queen might claim an audience of the King unbidden. Yet if he bent his golden sceptre towards her, the suppliant might approach; but the penalty was death, [masked clause describing a condition or proviso]. This was the risk she ran, and suddenly she appeared in all her beauty before him, the sceptre bent towards her and she made her request.

Write a clause appropriate for this book that could stand in the position marked by [masked clause describing a condition or proviso]:
source_title: The Temple of Solomon : a Review of the Various Theories Respecting its Form and Style of Architecture : the Ethics of art : two Lectures
answer_strings: if so be his pleasure was otherwise
if the King was well pleased
if I may so say
if indeed it was peculiar to it
unless he himself extended an invitation
unless she bears the sigil of the ancient house upon her breast
passage: "And so will I go in unto the King and if I perish I perish." A supreme self sacrifice for a Nation's redemption. There was a law that not even the Queen might claim an audience of the King unbidden. Yet if he bent his golden sceptre towards her, the suppliant might approach; but the penalty was death, if so be his pleasure was otherwise. This was the risk she ran, and suddenly she appeared in all her beauty before him, the sceptre bent towards her and she made her request.

metadata_frame: The following passage comes from The Temple of Solomon : a Review of the Various Theories Respecting its Form and Style of Architecture : the Ethics of art : two Lectures, a collection of lectures about art published in 1887 by Edward Cookworthy Robins, a British architect and author.
main_question:
Ezekiel, in his vision of the restored temple, tells us that "the side chambers were three, one over another, and thirty in order," that is, thirty in all on the sides of the house, besides those at the end of the oracle. Our ingenious friend, Josephus, finding that the phrase, "thirty in order," might be translated "three and thirty times," or thirty times three, says there were thirty chambers on each floor, in all ninety chambers-it mattered not to him how small they were in plan, [masked clause describing a cause or reason].

Write a clause appropriate for this book that could stand in the position marked by [masked clause describing a cause or reason]:
source_title: The Temple of Solomon : a Review of the Various Theories Respecting its Form and Style of Architecture : the Ethics of art : two Lectures
answer_strings: for what they lost in length he quadrupled in height
for what they gained in length, he halved in height

for the construction and adornment of his Temple and palace, represented the skill of the nation; it comprehended every branch of art, working in gold and silver, in brass and iron, in purple and blue, in stone and timber, in fine linen and in the engraving of precious stones
for their immediate neighbours, the Tyrians and Sidonians, have left no monuments either at home or abroad
provided he could accommodate his arbitrary view of the temple's dimensions
because his priority was the symbolic significance of the numbers rather than the precise dimensions
passage: Ezekiel, in his vision of the restored temple, tells us that "the side chambers were three, one over another, and thirty in order," that is, thirty in all on the sides of the house, besides those at the end of the oracle. Our ingenious friend, Josephus, finding that the phrase, "thirty in order," might be translated "three and thirty times," or thirty times three, says there were thirty chambers on each floor, in all ninety chambers-it mattered not to him how small they were in plan, for what they lost in length he quadrupled in height.

metadata_frame: The following passage comes from The Temple of Solomon : a Review of the Various Theories Respecting its Form and Style of Architecture : the Ethics of art : two Lectures, a collection of lectures about art published in 1887 by Edward Cookworthy Robins, a British architect and author.
main_question:
In this they were not singular, for their immediate neighbours, the Tyrians and Sidonians, have left no monuments either at home or abroad. Tyre, Sidon, Jerusalem, Baalbec, Palmyra, Carthage, possess no architectural antiquities anterior to Roman times, except perchance vast masses of masonry, the retaining walls of imposing platforms upon which were reared those structures which have since disappeared. The Jews, however, were by no means ignorant of the building arts, as practised by the Egyptians, but their ideas of building were all associated in their minds with bondage; [masked clause describing an inference or effect]. The two great authorities on the subject are, of course, the Bible itself and the Jewish historian, Josephus.

Write a clause appropriate for this book that could stand in the position marked by [masked clause describing an inference or effect]:
source_title: The Temple of Solomon : a Review of the Various Theories Respecting its Form and Style of Architecture : the Ethics of art : two Lectures
answer_strings: so that Solomon employed not his own people to build his Temple; of them it is distinctly stated he made captains and over-lookers only
so that Solomon appointed his own people to construct the temple, relying on Jews for menial labor
so far, drawn my illustrations from among historical painters, but the same principles are applicable to every form of art, whether it be painting, sculpture, architecture, music, or poetry
they avoided building stone structures as reminders of their enslavement in Egypt
this resulted in a cautious, restrained approach to monumental architecture
passage: In this they were not singular, for their immediate neighbours, the Tyrians and Sidonians, have left no monuments either at home or abroad. Tyre, Sidon, Jerusalem, Baalbec, Palmyra, Carthage, possess no architectural antiquities anterior to Roman times, except perchance vast masses of masonry, the retaining walls of imposing platforms upon which were reared those structures which have since disappeared. The Jews, however, were by no means ignorant of the building arts, as practised by the Egyptians, but their ideas of building were all associated in their minds with bondage; so that Solomon employed not his own people to build his Temple; of them it is distinctly stated he made captains and over-lookers only. The two great authorities on the subject are, of course, the Bible itself and the Jewish historian, Josephus.
